newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Former Brazil leader Franco plans 1998 comeback.
newsitem.headline: Former Brazil leader Franco plans 1998 comeback.

text.p: Former Brazilian President Itamar Franco said on Thursday he would leave his current post and run in next year's presidential race.

"I am, in effect, a candidate for the presidency of the republic," Franco told a news conference, where he announced he would resign as Brazil's representative to the Organisation of American States to concentrate on his campaign.

Franco was elected vice president under Fernando Collor in 1989 and became president in 1992 when Collor resigned over a corruption scandal. He has repeatedly hinted he might run for the top job in 1998 and claims he deserves credit for the Real Plan, an inflation-slashing economic programme introduced by his finance minister, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who is now president.

Brazil's constitution prevents presidents, state governors and mayors from running for second consecutive terms, but Cardoso was looking to the Senate to approve a constitutional amendment that would allow him to run for re-election next year. It has already been passed by the Chamber of Deputies.

Franco met Cardoso late on Wednesday to inform him of their likely showdown and said the president had found his decision "understandable." The former leader, who is not a member of any political party, said he would meet with left and right-wing parties to build a platform for his shot at the presidency.
An opinion poll published in March by the private Ibope polling company found Franco would win just 3 percent, compared with 46 percent for Cardoso, if the latter is allowed to run for a second term.
